Hmm so maybe theres no cure at all...

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Ninja Masters of America
messages.msgSnippet: Ok if one can not be a samurai and ninja where samurai how can there be ninjitsu?Michael Youngblood  wrote: My only question is this: is
messages.messageBody:
Ok if one can not be a samurai and ninja where samurai how can there be ninjitsu?Michael

Youngblood <warrior02@...> wrote:
My only question is this: is it the same
person/people as those who created the site, or is it
someone making their own spinoff to the saga?

That indeed is a good question and you are probably right. I realize the
site and the book is a parody, I have another word for it, but I would like
to keep it G Rated here.

I was merely answering the question that he was a child.

Mike
-------Original Message-------

From: Nate Ledbetter
Date: 05/30/05 23:54:04
To: samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Ninja Masters of America


--- Michael Youngblood <warrior02@...> wrote:
> If you do find a legit article I would very muck
> like to see it. This was
> the only article I've seen, and I had to hunt that
> one down. I was mistaken
> that it was CNN. when it was MSNBC, for that I
> apologize.

You had to hunt it down, because it's not REAL. It's
hosted off the UCLA website, which leads me to believe
it's the creation of one or more UCLA students, as a
joke. NOTHING comes up on the MSNBC site if you look
for anything related to this.

Not only is the website a parody, but all this
business about being in court and defecating is ALSO a
parody/joke. My only question is this: is it the same
person/people as those who created the site, or is it
someone making their own spinoff to the saga?

*sigh*

And people get upset when I lament the failure of
today's youth to grasp irony...

messages.messageBody:
Now that you mention it was a 13 year old it makes sense that they would do something like this. Its understandable but if it were to be an adult, well... Adults spending their time on this sort of thing? I didn't know the age of the person but as I mentioned before now it makes more sense. Only a child would spend their time on that sort of thing. But if it gets your jollies, who am I to criticize?

is very adept at parody.

> > page. but I don't think he
> > ever used it though.. good thing..
>
> Hmm. Okay then. I suppose accidental parody is better
> than none at all.
>


Well, for a 13 year old kid, he did an impressive job of publishing
his book: (if one link doesnt work, try the other)

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-
/080652569X/qid=1117530188/sr=8-1/ref=pd_csp_1/103-4665900-3762249?
v=glance&s=books&n=507846

http://tinyurl.com/d8je2

Editorial Reviews

Book Description
Dear Stupid Idiots,
A lot of you have been saying that I don't know anything about REAL
ninjas. But that's a bunch of bull crap! You dummies don't know
anything. And maybe YOU should get a life. I bet a lot of you have
never even seen a girl naked! You idiots believe that ninjas had
some "code of honor." Yeah right! If by "code of honor," you
mean "code to flip out and go nuts for absolutely no reason at all
even if it means that people might think you are totally insane or
sweet," then you are right. But if you mean a "code to be nice and
speak nicely while sharing and not cutting off heads," then you're
the biggest idiot ever!!!!!! So if you have any brains, you will
shut up and get a life. So go shut up, you stupid idiot.

No thank you,

Robert Hamburger


Review:

Ever have an obsession when you were a kid? Something you loved so
much that you couldn't stop talking about it to anyone and everyone?
Multiply that by 100 and you get Robert Hamburger, the fictional
author/protagonist of the book. While the book is primarily made up
of the same material that is posted on the website, the true point
of the book is hidden in it's footnotes. Through conversations with
his babysitter/co-writer, dog, parents and psychologist, we follow
Robert's story and delve into the psyche of a pretty messed up
little kid. What a lot of people dont seem to get is that the book,
like the site, isn't actually about Ninjas. It's not REALLY a ninja
hand guide, or a history lesson. The point isnt to educate, the
point is to tell the story of a troubled kid who buries himself in a
ninja fantasy in order to escape his negligant parents, over-
critical teachers and to compensate for his lack of friends. As a
kid we all had times when we wished we could run away to the circus,
or could go live in outer space, or whatever, because we felt like
we couldn't indentify with anyone.. this book is simply the story of
a kid going through that kind of period in his life. And for
everyone that claims that the website and the book may cause kids
to "flip out and kill each other," I believe that the book actually
encourages the exact opposite. Robert is facsinated with killing and
violence because it's what he wants to do to the people that have
hurt him in his life, or he wants to find a ninja friend to do it...
hell, we've seen children and young adults in this situation before
a few years back, and we've seen the consequences of such pent up
anger. This book is not an advocate of violence, but a warning as to
what can happen when we try to force kids to abandon childish
things, pump them full of medicine and "discipline" in order to make
them grow up fast, rather than encourage them to be silly, dream and
savor every momment of their childhood. I for one did not expect
this level of complexity in this book, but I was totally floored
after finishing it. Comedy, especially parody, has always been the
best forum for social commentary, and this book masters it. If you
hate the site, or if you don't get it, spend the $10 and read the
book and I'm pretty sure you'll change your opinion. This book is
genius: and by genius, I mean totally sweet.

good fake of an MSNBC article. None of the links at
the bottom seem to work (They all direct you to
another www.bol.ucla.edu site, not to any actual MSNBC
site), and I highly doubt anyone with any sense of
journalistic pride would actually type "laid a log" in
a real story.

up with anything other than this, links to the site,
and links to message boards debating whether he's for
real. (I'm excluding the numerous hits for Robert
Hamburger, genetics researcher--apparently he shares
the name, unfortunately).

I'm going to try to check this out some more, but so
far, I'm not buying it.

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Ninja Masters of America
messages.msgSnippet: ... The problem is, just about anyone can update IMDB. The only source that says Hayes was in Shogun is Hayes himself. If someone at the IMDB wanted to verify
messages.messageBody:
Michael wrote:

> The best source to find that is the movie database. Here is Hayes's
> profile. http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0371230/

The problem is, just about anyone can update IMDB. The only source that says
Hayes was in Shogun is Hayes himself. If someone at the IMDB wanted to verify
it, they would contact Hayes and ask him if he was in it. All he has to do is
say "yes."

Short of that, one has no recourse but to contact the studio and ask for
25-year-old records on payments made for extras. And, frankly, I doubt they have
those at this point. At any rate, being a guy who falls off the rigging is the
type of job that would be given to a professional stuntman, not some random guy
off the street extra. Not to mention it's hardly a claim to fame.

I think this claim, like so many others he makes, is pure BS.


Tony
--

messages.msgSnippet: Ok a rare post from me moment. We all seem to be getting a little off topic with the whole ninja topic. From my perspective (24yro) I find that the ninja have
messages.messageBody:
Ok a rare post from me moment. We all seem to be getting a little off topic with the whole ninja topic. From my perspective (24yro) I find that the ninja have somewhat been given a superhero mythical status. Im a firm believer in classical arts and that the modern day version of a ninja is nothing more than a perversion of history, On one of the forums in which I moderate there a forum ninjas ( moderators) this kinda shows how to be a ninja is uber cool!! ( and trust me these guys have never even heard the word Iga ,let alone looked at ninja history) I also believe that modern day ninja are a 20th century interpretation of what we would want them to be, almost comic book in fact. I not sure if the western worlds interpretation of ninja is directly responsable for the ninja fad,or that the ninjas own secerecy and art of deception is responsible for leaving blanks in which peoples 'poetic licence' run amuck.

ROD PAVEZ <grfkboyz@...> wrote:I apologize Nate. I'v been out of town awhile and haven't checked my email recently. Now that you mention its a parody I still wonder why anyone would waste their time on creating a site that pokes fun at the perspective most Americans have of ninja. I mean will it change the attitude? Somebody's wasting their time I think. And definitely sarcasm is not something you spare Nate.
Later.

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Ninja Masters of America
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Carl, ... Hope you enjoyed it, it is supposed to be fun after all:-) ... No I didn t, but then the series isn t history either, it s just a great romp, plus
messages.messageBody:
Hi Carl,

> hey,i was just lookin at the shogun page

Hope you enjoyed it, it is supposed to be fun after all:-)

>hahaha coincidentally did
> you know that mr hayes,was actually an actor in the original movie
> shogun?no bs

No I didn't, but then the series isn't history either, it's just a great
romp, plus it's what got me started down the road to real Japanese
history, as with so many others of us in the West. So I have personally
a great debt of gratitude to Clavell for writing it, I just wish he'd
followed the original story a wee bit closer!

>.oh,and the photo of the samurai playing go....samurai
> would not sit like that.atleast not in the presence of others.

Yep, can't fault you on that one, you're absolutely right, but I'm old,
grey haired, grumpy, and my knees no longer like being sat on, plus
after many years of wearing combat boots, my ankles object to bending
quite that far. And besides, it had been a long hot day and my old bones
just wanted to go flomp on the deck. And to cap it all, I'm virtually
blind, and if I sat properly I'd never be able to see the board, mind
you it wouldn't have made much difference to the outcome of that
particular game:-) Seppuku anybody?

Yours

Dean

P.S. For those who don't know what Carl is referring to when he say's
"Shogun page", see my link below and all will be revealed.
***
Dean Wayland
Head Of The Fight School
http://www.thefightschool.demon.co.uk/SHOGUN.htm

messages.subject: Re: Ninja Masters of America
messages.msgSnippet: hey,i was just lookin at the shogun page,hahaha coincidentally did you know that mr hayes,was actually an actor in the original movie shogun? Well, Hayes
messages.messageBody:
" hey,i was just lookin at the shogun page,hahaha coincidentally did
you know that
mr hayes,was actually an actor in the original movie shogun?"

Well, Hayes CLAIMS he was, anyway. He is uncredited and the detailed
list of cast & crew (including stunt personnel) I have gives no mention
of him. The only other place I've ever seen it mentioned was in an
interview with Hayes (of course) in Kick magazine back in the 80's
where among other things he claims to have been living in Japan for
years, given the Shogun production crew ninja history and choreography
for the ninja attack sequence, and just totally impressed the whole
crew with his grasp of Japanese history and martial arts. The part he
was supposed to have played was a stuntman part-the crewman that falls
off the mast of the Erasmus into the ocean.
Perhaps some clever Japanese solution to get rid of the
gaijin 'expert'...

messages.msgSnippet: Actually it was a kid who wrote it, and has been in and out of the courts for quite a while to ban his website and erase the material that is on it, but he is
messages.messageBody:
Actually it was a kid who wrote it, and has been in and out of the courts
for quite a while to ban his website and erase the material that is on it,
but he is protected from the first amendment so they cannot stop his website


He is even the author of a book. at the time he was 13 years old. His book
is even banned in some states, cities, and book stores. I actually saw the
book in a book store and I peeked into it for a bit, and laughed at it.
there is not one speck of real Ninpo in the entire book. now I read that he
was found not guilty he hugged the woman that was suing him, and then pulled
down his pants and defecated on the floor on the way out of court saying
that is real ultimate power" and vanished. Now I do not know if that is true
or not but it seems to be in news sites including CNN..

Mike

-------Original Message-------

From: ROD PAVEZ
Date: 05/29/05 19:47:17
To: samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Ninja Masters of America

Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!!!!! Who in God's name created that site. It reads
like a child wrote it. Ninja just flip out and kill people? Ha, ha, ha!!!!
Somebody put the author out of his misery, please!

Dean Wayland <dean@...> wrote:Hi Maikeru,

> You know what I realized afte rlooking at Stephen Hayes dojo site.
> His
> buisness is shady at best.
>
> To go to one of his seminars it costs $300. And supposing I was
> dumb
> enough to want to teach his stuff at a dojo I would have to buy the
> dvd on which class I want to teach, watch it, then send mor emoney
> to
> have a curriculum sent to me.
>
> http://www.skhquest.com/
>
> Sorry to ressurect the whole Hayes thing, but god is there no
> decency.
>
> Maikeru

Firstly, thanks for posting Hayes' URL, it was interesting to visit the
"horse's mouth(?)":-)

I think the answer to your last question is sadly no. However, Kitsuno
had previously put up the following link as an antidote for such woes,
so if you missed it, please go and enjoy:

http://www.realultimatepower.net/index4.htm

Now, seriously, as a re-enactor of Japanese history I am forever having
to explain, that in my opinion virtually the whole "ninja" thing is pure
baloney, although I do put it more politely than that normally. Does
anyone know of a web site that deals with this topic in a genuinely
scholarly fashion? So far, all I can find are the usual crop of ninja
wanabe dojo's, or those frothing at the mouth with their pre-pubescent
fantasies, as for the rest: - silence.

Cepo wrote that he had read mountains of books for his Phd, and not one
mention of the ninja, which to me is dam fine evidence. But what I need
to be able to point folks at is a reputable and scholarly discussion of
the subject, preferably short, putting the ninja in (or out of) their
historical context, citing the evidence one way or another. The trouble
is when I tried to write a short piece for my website, I realised, that
I'm massively unqualified to do it any kind of credible justice. So,
help!

I suspect that there is nothing out there as this whole subject has a
pariah quality about it, meaning that to date any scholar worth their
salt, treats it like a hot potato and leaves the topic well alone! Oh
well...

Yours

Dean
Definitely not a secret mystical ninja master from England, unless you
know otherwise:-)
***

Dean Wayland
Head Of The Fight School
http://www.thefightschool.demon.co.uk

anyone know of a web site that deals with this topic in a genuinely
scholarly fashion? So far, all I can find are the usual crop of ninja
wanabe dojo's, or those frothing at the mouth with their pre-pubescent
fantasies, as for the rest: - silence.

Cepo wrote that he had read mountains of books for his Phd, and not one
mention of the ninja, which to me is dam fine evidence. But what I need
to be able to point folks at is a reputable and scholarly discussion of
the subject, preferably short, putting the ninja in (or out of) their
historical context, citing the evidence one way or another. The trouble
is when I tried to write a short piece for my website, I realised, that
I'm massively unqualified to do it any kind of credible justice. So,
help!

I suspect that there is nothing out there as this whole subject has a
pariah quality about it, meaning that to date any scholar worth their
salt, treats it like a hot potato and leaves the topic well alone! Oh
well...

Yours

Dean
Definitely not a secret mystical ninja master from England, unless you
know otherwise:-)
***

Dean Wayland

messages.subject: Re: new subject
messages.msgSnippet: Date Masamune sent a mission to Rome via the Americas and Spain in 1614. Hasekura Tsunenaga was the senior Japanese official, but whilst away Ieyasu turned
messages.messageBody:
Date Masamune sent a mission to Rome via the Americas and Spain in
1614.

Hasekura Tsunenaga was the senior Japanese official, but whilst away
Ieyasu turned against the Christians, word of which reached Rome,
and the mission returned having achieved nothing some 4 years later.

The Franciscan monk Fr Luis Sotelo, who organised the mission, had in
mind a crusade to convert Japan, and thus realise his own ambition of
becoming the Primate of that country.

Thomas

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] new subject
messages.msgSnippet: ... Several noble youths from Kyushu families were sent in the 1580 s. They went to Portugal, Spain, and Italy, and were received by the Pope. I m sure if you
messages.messageBody:
--- james wallis <kentguy212002@...> wrote:

>
> Hi , and hello and merry christmas to you all!!! .I
> was wondering today that when christianity was
> introduced to japan did any daimyo/ or current
> shogun send any envoys to the pope.Im sure that
> there is some vague record of japanese retainers
> attending the vatican , so does anybody know
> anything similiar.

Several noble youths from Kyushu families were sent in
the 1580's. They went to Portugal, Spain, and Italy,
and were received by the Pope. I'm sure if you did a
google search you could find most of the details.
Sansom covers it in his volume 2, and there are
several other sources out there. And interesting read
would be "The Samurai" by Endo Shusaku--fictional
account of a samurai journeying to Europe.

If I may, I would like to add my two cents here. With all due
respect, this is a topic that should not get started. it will be a
see-saw battle and no one will win. somebody has something different
to say on who is right and who is wrong. I have seen stories on
every Ninjutsu instructor out there from Frank Dux to Shoto
Tanamura, to Hatsumi Sensei himself. so wheather you are Dux-Ryu,
Genbukan, Bujinkan, Toshindo, Koga ryu, or even *sigh* Ashida Kim
lets keep the political bickering out of this one and just focus on
the true ninja history, please?

Mike

messages.messageBody:
HI

the Dux movie where he claims to have ocme form a
ninja family fought the ultimate contest has since
been proven fake. He even had a well publicised court
case between himself and Van Damm which he lost. Even
Dux military past has been proven fake.

Hayes, well reading his books, and oing my own
research it has to say somehting if Hayes and my self
are in the same org as each other and I wont train
with him.

paul



--- Silk Road School <silk.road.school@...>
wrote:


---------------------------------

--- Nate Ledbetter <ltdomer98@...> wrote:

Now, if you want to start quoting Stephen
Hayes
(Explanation: I'm currently putting myself through the
agony of reading his book--and I use that term only
because it has pages and is bound--about the mystical
origins of Ninjutsu--insert appropriate oohs and ahs
here.

Years ago, when I was working in a bookstore in L.A.,
I knew some fellows
studying with Frank Dux as well as some studying with
Stephen Hayes. As I
was certain that Dux was a fraud (a very fast,
legitimately deadly fraud,
with some frighteningly effective moves, but still
nothing like the adopted
son of an Old Ninja Family that he pretended to be), I
called up Hayes at
his studio and asked him something about research. I
was thinking about
getting the store to stock some of his books. I have
rarely made anyone so
nervous in a first conversation. It set off my
internal alarms, and I never
did order the books.
Gereg
P.S. Ooh. Ah. (Almost forgot that.)

messages.messageBody:
--- Nate Ledbetter <ltdomer98@...> wrote:

Now, if you want to start quoting Stephen
Hayes
(Explanation: I'm currently putting myself through the
agony of reading his book--and I use that term only
because it has pages and is bound--about the mystical
origins of Ninjutsu--insert appropriate oohs and ahs
here.

Years ago, when I was working in a bookstore in L.A., I knew some fellows
studying with Frank Dux as well as some studying with Stephen Hayes. As I
was certain that Dux was a fraud (a very fast, legitimately deadly fraud,
with some frighteningly effective moves, but still nothing like the adopted
son of an Old Ninja Family that he pretended to be), I called up Hayes at
his studio and asked him something about research. I was thinking about
getting the store to stock some of his books. I have rarely made anyone so
nervous in a first conversation. It set off my internal alarms, and I never
did order the books.
Gereg
P.S. Ooh. Ah. (Almost forgot that.)
